title: Boris Johnson should not bet on winning over Labour Leave voters
text:

In elections voters can be both punitive and forgiving.



They are ruthless if they sense weakness, dishonesty and division.



They are forgiving if they believe you are trying to do the right thing and are genuine in your intentions.



The problem for Jeremy Corbyn is that he falls into both these categories.



Voters do not regard him as a Prime Minister in waiting and they have seen through his triangulation on Brexit.



But many, perhaps enough to see Labour do better than expected, like Labour’s policies, its fight against injustice and its determination to fix the broken state.



The key to this election will be whether Labour can play to its strengths while minimising its weaknesses.



(Image: Peter Summers)



Traditional Labour voters could come back to the fold during the campaign if they are inspired by Labour’s message or fearful a vote elsewhere could see the Tories govern for another five years.



Labour will struggle if Boris Johnson is allowed to frame the campaign almost entirely on getting Brexit done.



Although the Tories are trying to blunt Labour’s strongest attack lines by offering to reverse the cuts to the police and the health service - cuts they were originally responsible for - they could be vulnerable to a backlash from voters who may decide the state of their local hospital, the cuts to their local school and the closure of their local library are of a more immediate concern than getting a deal with Brussels.

There is no escaping the fact that many Labour MPs are pessimistic about their prospects.



You can gauge the mood by the fact that nearly half the parliamentary party declined to vote for the election in last night’s vote .



I’ve set out here ten ways that could see Labour over the finishing line.

(Image: PA)





Few expect Jeremy Corbyn to get an overall majority but there is a path, albeit a slim one, to Labour emerging as the largest party.



To set the scene we have the final PMQs today before the campaign begins in earnest next week.



Boris Johnson and Jeremy Corbyn will seek to rally their troops and test out their messaging.

Much will depend on the Brexit Party which has been, from Labour’s point of view, ominously silent about its intentions.



If Nigel Farage’s outfit continues to poll at around 8% then it could deny Tories victory in a string of marginal seats.



Conversely, if Remain voters cannot decide between Labour and the Lib Dems then Johnson could be gifted power without having to do any heavy lifting.



To give you an idea of how volatile and unpredictable this election is there are 31 constituencies held by a majority of fewer than 500 votes.



Many of these are four or five-way seats where a handful of votes could decide not just the local outcome but the national one.



Today's agenda:



9.50am - Woman and Equalities committee takes evidence on prostitution.



10am - Interim report on the Grenfell fire tragedy is published.



11.30pm - Northern Ireland questions in the Commons.



12pm - Boris Johnson and Jeremy Corbyn at Prime Minister’s questions. For one of them it will be for the last time.



12.45pm (approx) - Debate on the Grenfell fire tragedy.



What I am reading:



Jeremy Corbyn in the Mirror on Labour’s election plans
description: A handful of votes in a handful of seats could determine the result of the general election
